What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course for a follow up to AP Calculus AB. Someone who took AP Calc AB will be plenty prepared for this course.
I gained insights into Calculus II along with real life applications of the concepts we developed.

I furthered my knowledge of calculus and developed critical thinking skills. I also learned how to manage my time better with this course because the problem sets were challenging enough that it was definitely worth it to start earlier.
Anti derivatives, series and sequences, polar/parametric
Complex problem solving and calculus.
I learned how to study for classes like this.
An understanding of integral calculus.

Problem-solving, persistence, time-management
The class was definitely very fast-paced so I had to learn how to stay on top of my work
Calculus II: advanced integration strategies, power series, integral approximations, calculus with polar and parametric functions
Integration, volume approximation. etc.
Learning methods of integrals and series.
Thorough understanding of integration techniques and series. Just regular Calc 2, as you probably know.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths are the structure of the course. I really liked how the class was broken up into sections and I think the smaller class size fostered a better learning environment. I do not really see any weaknesses.
Great class, but I wish there was more practice material for exams. The PSETs weren't really like the tests at all, and the practice tests for midterms weren't enough practice material

The scheduling of the course seemed like it didn't always align with problem sets. I remember a problem set being due on a given Wednesday and then learning a concept that was being assessed on the problem set the day after it was due in class. Besides that the virtual lectures were still effective in delivering content. The only thing that I would recommend is having a TA or two in each lecture to go around and help the professor with breakout room work.
It was difficult to learn remotely. It would have been nice to have had the classes recorded.
For virtual learning, course was taught very well. Lectures were engaging (for a covid year), and course material was taught in a very digestible way.
The professor was great and explained all the concepts throughly. There were also a lot of resources available to the students. I do not think there are any major weaknesses.

I think some of the weaknesses of this course was that a lot of time it was very hard to digest material because every class we were learning new material. Some of the strengths were that the course load was pretty manageable with just one p-set a week and I found the explorations very helpful.

I thought this course moved at the perfect pacewe covered a lot of ground with each class, but never so much that I felt lost. At the same time, I sometimes felt as if we hadn't covered all the topics necessary to answer some of the p-set questions; I spent a lot of time reading the textbook on my own and also searching things up online.
Strengths: extremely well organized in Canvas, great instructor, well organized course overall. Weaknesses: not much of a break on problem sets on the week of midterms, but honestly nothing else.

Strength
- lots of resources for help
Lots of in-depth instruction. Could use more difficult examples such as those on psets and exams.

One of the strengths was Brett Smith, who is an experienced and very approachable professor. He is always available and highly encourages his students to come to him for any help or guidance. If you take this course, I recommend you take his specific section. The only weakness is the content, which can often feel detached from its applications, since this is an introductory course focused mainly on honing in the skills rather than exploring how they are applied in the real world. Often times, this made the class boring, but that is to be expected from an introductory math course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class made me feel engaged over zoom which was wonderful. The professor would constantly have polls and ask for people to explain their answer choices and reasoning. He also used breakout rooms in every class which helped break the monotony of just sitting and watching the professor.

Like I said in my last response, I think the breakout rooms are great for individuals to work together to test their understanding of the material being taught in lecture, but if they get stuck the professor isn't always there to help because they have to bounce around from group to group. I think that having a TA or two in the class that could assist the professor with these sorts of things would be beneficial.
Lectures could have been recorded with less breakout rooms.
The expected participation in lectures was very helpfulespecially breakout rooms. Overall, I thought the virtual practices were as good as they couldve been.
I think the addition of breakout rooms for the course was really helpful.
The lectures were great and I enjoyed all of the prerecorded videos available. I do not think any major improvements need to be made.

Professor Smith would frequently "poll" the class on the answers to various multiple questions, which really helped me stay engaged in class. Although the breakout rooms seemed like another good way to keep us engaged, I ended up in a breakout room where everyone kept their camera off and no one would discuss the questions with me. Perhaps this could have been remedied if we had switched breakout rooms partway through the term or had simply been in a different breakout room every time.

The course took full advantage of Canvas and its features to keep things organized. It was also helpful that the instructor encouraged everyone to have their cameras on to make as much of a classroom experience as possible. The course also took full advantage of breakout rooms in Zoom which helped create a space for smaller scale collaboration. Not much could be changed to improve in terms of virtual engagement!
Break out rooms are difficult to engage with.

Breakout rooms are effective only in theory. Most of the times, it was filled with award mumblings and proceedings that did not further my understanding of the class or the materials. Time would have been better spent in lecture.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course with Professor Smith. He really cares about his students and is super responsive. He always encourages people to come to his office hours and he even made an effort to have personal meetings with our "groups" to discover our current thoughts on the class and ways to improve. The class itself is well structured. The problem sets are reasonable and workload is very manageable.
Yes! Especially with Brett Smith
I would recommend this course to anybody looking to continue climbing the ladder in math.

If they don't need this class for their major, I don't think the rigor of this class is worth it. Especially for how much you actually apply these concepts in real world scenarios. I would also say that if it is required for your major that you shouldn't be scared of it because the profs are very flexible and extremely helpful both in helping directly and showing you resources that you have at your disposal.
Yes. The material is important.
Yes. Course was taught very well, and the material was interesting (standard Calc 2 topics).
Yes. If a student wants to further their math knowledge and learn from an excellent teacher.
Only if you need it for your major.

I frequently despised math in high school, but this course actually made me like the subject. The problem sets and exam questions make you think while still being fairly manageable, especially if you go to office hours.

Yes! For prerequisites and/or distribution credits or just for the sake of learning, it is absolutely necessary to have a good foundation in integral calculus, and the course is very well set up such that it is a great experience learning about it!
Yes
Yes great faculty and interesting material.
Do not take this solely to fulfill your QR credits. Only take it if it is a requirement. Not a fun class, but a necessary one for certain STEM fields.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Textbook
Synchronous peer tutoring sessions and review sessions were offered.
None
Virtual lecture with discussions throughout.
Although this course primarily operated as a lecture, Professor Smith frequently asked questions and also tried to put us into one breakout room every class, which provided ample room for discussion.
virtual section
Supplemental videos on subjects from he math department
Pre-class worksheets
n/a
